nodes.bodyText:
The level of abstraction is perhaps inconsistent here, would you agree @RoiEXLab ?
Notably, we have a high level call PasswordBCrypter.hashPasswordWithSalt, which abstracts away parameters and configuration, then we have a more low level call to verify.
Second, the params to verifyer seem to be chosen for specific reasons, but it's not immediately clear (missing context) what those reasons were.
I think you could resolve both concerns by moving the verifyer call to a similar static method. That method could then be documented to note why the parameters are chosen as they are, and we'd have a consistent abstraction in this method. For example:
final String hashedPassword = PasswordBCrypter.hashPasswordWithSalt(password);
return BcryptedPasswordVerifyer.verify(hashedPassword);

WDYT @RoiEXLab ?
(A third benefit, we would not need to repeat the verifyer parameters in test, DRY)

Really similar to my other comment, I think we may benefit to create a utility method around this hasing method:

provides a good place to document decisions/parameters:

why '10'?
why 'LongPasswordStrategies.none()'?


Avoids repetition between source code and test (DRY)

Are we still using a bcrypt salt anywhere?
If not, for this PR or a fast-follow, we can clean up the configuration that was intended to inject a salt:

https://github.com/triplea-game/triplea/blob/master/http-server/src/main/java/org/triplea/server/http/AppConfig.java#L57
https://github.com/triplea-game/triplea/blob/master/http-server/configuration.yml#L12
https://github.com/triplea-game/triplea/blob/master/infrastructure/ansible/roles/http_server/templates/configuration.yml.j2#L8
https://github.com/triplea-game/triplea/blob/master/infrastructure/ansible/roles/http_server/defaults/main.yml#L20

I'm not sure what you mean by that.
Obviously a salt is still generated for the individual passwords, you just don't have to manually supply them any longer.
Good news - That means the AppConfig scaffolding added for it, and never wired fully to be used, can be removed as it'll never be used.
